thread.title: Woodstock boys, Etowah girls have the edge on drenched Boling Park course
thread.title_full: Woodstock boys, Etowah girls have the edge on drenched Boling Park course

author: Alex Resnak aresnak@cherokeetribune.com (noreply@cherokeetribune.com)
title: Woodstock boys, Etowah girls have the edge on drenched Boling Park course
text: Woodstock boys, Etowah girls have the edge on drenched Boling Park course by Alex Resnak October 11, 2015 12:41 AM | 539 views | 0 | 2 | | Cherokee’s Taylor Scarbrough (53) pulls away from a group of Etowah runners through a wet, muddy course in Saturday morning’s county meet at Boling Park. Scarbrough went on to defend his county title, but in a time that was well off his winning pace of a year ago. Staff photo by Kelly J. Huff Macki Walsh won for the Etowah girls, pacing the Lady Eagles’ run to the team championship. Staff photo by Kelly J. Huff slideshow CANTON — On a wet, sloppy course at Boling Park, the Woodstock boys and Etowah girls clinched the team championships in Saturday morning’s county meet.In the boys race, Woodstock (36 points) edged Etowah (44) and Creekview (87), while the girls race saw Etowah (26) keep a pack near the front the entire race and hold off Creekview (44) and Woodstock (65).Individually, Cherokee’s Taylor Scarbrough dominated the boys race, crossing the line in 16 minutes, 32.74 second and beating Etowah’s Blake Beavers by more than 10 seconds.“It felt great to get a win, but it was super sloppy out there compared to last year,” said Scarbrough, who won last year’s race in 15:46. “I was slipping a lot, and I couldn’t get any traction. Everything hurts, and everything’s harder. I was just able to keep moving and come out on top.”Zack Driscoll also ran well for Cherokee, finishing sixth in 17:05.23, but those were the only top-25 finishes for Warriors, who finished fourth as a team with 98 points.After Scarbrough were two Etowah runners, Beavers (16:43.16) and Nick Cooke (third, 16:51.24). They were the only other runners to break the 17-minute barrier.“They were really bad conditions,” Beavers said. “It was not a good place to (set a personal record), because the water was always ankle-deep and the dirt was all mud. I knew coming in, based on my fitness, I had a chance to take first or second. I’m just glad I was able to come out and do what I knew I could do.”Marc Reiser also scored a top-10 finish for Etowah, placing ninth in 17:14.55. Sam Donley (14th, 17:27.36) and Dylan Simpson (16th, 17:32.62) were the other scoring runners for the Eagles.Woodstock handled the conditions better than any other boys team, finishing all seven runners in the top 17 and finishing all of its qualifying runners in the top 12.Corey Champion (17:00.88) and Austin Bailey (17:03.38) led the way for the Wolverines, finishing fourth and fifth, respectively. Kyle Pawlowski (seventh, 17:07.75) and Josiah Jaqua (eighth, 17:08.74) also finished in the top 10 for, while Patrick Nolan (12th, 17:22.42) rounded out Woodstock’s scoring runners.Creekview’s third-place finish was led by two runners near the front. Nick Turano (10th, 17:19.65) and Wade Whitfield (11th, 17:20.23) were the Grizzlies’ top finishers.Sequoyah finished fifth with 103 points and was paced by Braeden Kelly (15th, 17:30.06) and Josh Meyers (19th, 17:39.89). River Ridge, led by Jack Collins (31st, 18:30.04), finished sixth with 171 points. Etowah’s Macki Walsh took the girls race in 19:26.74 and saw four of her teammates also finish in the top 10.“It feels really good to see my team right behind me,” Walsh said. “It’s nice to see a really strong team performance. I feel like an individual win and a team win are about even, because we feel a lot of pride in both of them.”Madison Fowler (fourth, 20:15.82), Shelby Rensel (fifth, 20:34.43), Kyla Resnick (seventh, 20:53.05) and Beth Haynes (ninth, 21:00.01) also contributed for the Lady Eagles.Woodstock’s Brynne Sumner was second in 19:28.61, more than 15 seconds ahead of the third-place runner. She said her preparation made a difference in the adverse conditions.“The mud gets in your face, and there are a lot of puddles,” she said. “It came down to all my training and hard work I had to put in.”Bailie McInnis (sixth, 20:47.00) also ran well for the Lady Wolverines, while Anna Bailey finished 14th in 21:15.59.Lauren Wallin, who finished third in 19:44.25, paced a strong showing by Creekview that saw all seven of its runners finish in the top 15. Molly Morris finished eighth in 20:57.22, while Sarah Disharoon (10th, 21:01.92), Bella Thomas (11th, 21:05.00) and Dara Staton (12th, 21:05.28) finished as a pack to round out Creekview’s scoring.Paced by RaeAnna Starosciak (17th, 21:18.64) and Gabby Beck (19th, 21:24.87), Cherokee finished fourth with 116 points.Madison Stout was Sequoyah’s fastest runner, finishing 20th in 21:35.28, while December Weir led the way for River Ridge, finishing 28th in 23:36.32. Sequoyah (148) and River Ridge (163) were fifth and sixth as a team, respectively. Share This Article | similar stories
